review name: Makes a decent cuppa, but the parts are plastic.
review text:
I've been using my Keurig for several weeks now. It's performed fairly well and seems to be easy to operate and clean. I have some observations and notes to offer here.

The term "Multistream Technology" is really just marketing fluff. Instead of a single water stream, it's distributed across the coffee ground surface via more holes for water. Coffee makers have been doing this for years, it's not a "technology", it's actually common sense.

Despite the unit's appearance, nearly the entirety of this device is plastic, including the prongs that create holes into the pod seal and disperse water--the prongs are colored to appear metallic. The reason for the use of plastic is cost which has allowed Keurig to achieve a significant markup from their base production cost.

That being said, it works very well and makes decent coffee. I would prefer metallic hardware, I'd pay more for it happily, as I don't like the clumsy feel of plastic. Box also didn't indicate whether this is BPA free, as I recall.

I had a Keurig for years and enjoyed the coffee. However, the new multi stream (punches 5 holes for water to pass through) this technology enhances the deepness and richness of the flavor of the coffee. It is amazing how good it is and it is hotter as well.

Would give 10 stars if available. Highly, highly recommend!

review name: Plastic machine feels cheap and flimsy, caught fire while brewing a cup
review text:
I've owned 2 Keurig K Supreme machines over the past 12 years and have been very pleased with them. The Supreme machines are heavier and solid, they're easy to maintain. Most importantly, they brew a great cup of coffee quickly with no fuss, muss or backtalk. With proper care, they work beautifully for 10+ years. My current K Supreme Plus was mistakenly put into storage during a move so I purchased this smaller model until I can go retrieve my big machine in the spring.

This model is all plastic and feels very flimsy when closing the top. It makes decent coffee but doesn't feel durable. After approx 6 weeks of daily use, 1 cup per day, this machine started making snap-cracking electrical sounds during the brew cycle. When I stepped near to listen, the machine suddenly erupted in fire and immediately was furiously burning and melting, giving off toxic fumes and threatening to ignite the cabinets above the machine. Thankfully, I had a can of fire extinguisher in arm's reach and was able to quickly put out the fire. If I had not been standing right there when it happened this incident could easily have resulted in a house fire. The fumes from the burning/melting plastic were painful to lungs and stunk up the house. Cleaning up the charred, melted plastic was difficult and time consuming, the plastic had liquified and stuck to the countertop and the ceramic mug.

There were no exposed wires or obvious problems that might have caused this fire. I have never in all of my decades of adulthood had any kitchen appliance start a fire. I will stick with the higher end Keurig models but I would never buy or gift one of these little plastic models again.

2. It's way less complicated than the old one. It automatically powers on when you open the K-cup compartment. You load your K-cup, prefilled or reusable. You close the breach and press and select your cup size, by pushing one of the three cup size buttons, then press start. Just make sure there's an adequately-sized cup wating for the brew to be dispensed into. And it will shut off automatically if you forget to power it off.
3. It's got a clear reservoir for water, so it keeps the process simple.

I can sit at the kitchen table 12 feet away and forget I'm making coffee until the aroma wafts over to me. It is amazingly quiet, especially if you've ever owned an older Keurig model. I'd dare say this model is as quiet as a traditional drip coffeemaker.
5. This Multi-Stream Technology is the real deal. It is exactly what I hoped it would be. Precisely as advertised. The coffee it makes, and I'm talking about a 12 oz. cup, has the strength and body and rich flavor I could never achieve with the old Keurig. It. Is. Glorious.
6. This creature costs half of what I paid for my original Keurig. So, you're getting an awesome deal here.
